0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Burn, Debridement of severe burn: apply TOPICAL ointment directly to wound daily (or more frequently if dressing becomes soiled); may also apply to sterile gauze pad that will be applied and secured to wound
  • Nipple tenderness: apply 4 times a day after breast-feeding
  • Skin ulcer (Chronic): apply TOPICAL ointment directly to ulcer daily (or more frequently if the dressing become soiled); may also apply to sterile gauze pad that will be applied and secured to ulcer

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in children

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Burn, Debridement of severe burn
  • Skin ulcer (Chronic)
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Nipple tenderness
  • Peyronie's disease
  • Prolapsed lumbar intervertebral disc

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to collagenase, local or systemic

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• debilitated patients; theoretical risk of bacteremia; monitoring recommended
  • detergents, acid solutions, or antiseptics containing heavy metal ions (eg, mercury or silver); may inactivate collagenase; avoid use
  • optimally effective at a pH of 6 to 8

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Collagenase is an enzyme from the fermentation of Clostridium histolyticum that has the ability to digest collagen in necrotic tissue. It helps in the formation of granulation tissues and epithelization of dermal ulcers and burned areas.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • remove loosened detritus prior to application
  • prior to application, clean wound by gently rubbing with a gauze pad saturated with NS (or with hydrogen peroxide or Dakin's solution); follow with NS rinse
  • crosshatching thick eschar with a #10 blade allows increased surface contact with necrotic debris
  • apply to sterile gauze or directly onto wound

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduced ulcer
  • evidence of wound closure
  • signs and symptoms of bacterial infections

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause transient erythema.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of wound infection.
  • Advise patient on proper application to wound.
  • Patient should not use other skin care products on treated area, unless approved by healthcare professional.
